title: Artificial Intelligence to Predict the BRAF V595E Mutation in Canine Urinary Bladder Urothelial Carcinomas
data_heterogeneity: The study mentions the use of a single institution's data with one specific scanner, indicating limited heterogeneity in data collection methods.
preprocessing: DNA extraction using QIAamp DNA FFPE Tissue Kit, PCR with mutation-specific TaqMan assay, histological analysis with HE staining and digital scanning.
evaluation_metrics: Chi-square test for associations between AI-based BRAF prediction and various factors like quality, morphology, inflammation, and invasion.
performance_results: 72% of cases were BRAF mutation positive as identified by PCR, with various threshold analyses for mutation prediction.
species_breed: Canine, specifically a 9-year-old Flat-coated Retriever mentioned
ml_algorithm: Deep learning classifiers with thresholds (0.5, 0.6, 0.7) for mutation prediction
data_type: Whole slide images (WSI) of HE stained tissue sections on glass slides
ai_goal: To predict the BRAF V595E mutation in canine urinary bladder urothelial carcinomas

title: Automatic gross tumor segmentation of canine head and neck cancer using deep learning and cross-species transfer learning
data_heterogeneity: Data from both human and canine datasets were used, with inherent differences in anatomy and disease characteristics between species.
preprocessing: Images were cropped and/or padded to standardize dimensions, with added voxels given a value corresponding to background/air.
evaluation_metrics: Dice similarity coefficient, true positive rate (TPR), positive predictive value (PPV), Hausdorff distance (HD95)
performance_results: Transfer learning model achieved a maximum Dice of 0.89 and a minimum ASD of 1.3 mm. Canine-only model showed higher tumor coverage but included more normal tissue.
ai_goal: To evaluate the applicability of deep learning-based automatic segmentation of the gross tumor volume (GTV) in canine patients with head and neck cancer.

title: Machine learning to detect leptospirosis
performance_results: BW model: Sensitivity 100%, Specificity 90.9%, AUC 0.955; BW+MAT model: Sensitivity 100%, Specificity 93.2%, AUC 0.959

title: A methodological approach for deep learning to distinguish between meningiomas and gliomas on canine MR-images
data_heterogeneity: Data from two different institutions with varying imaging protocols
preprocessing: Images exported in .jpg from DICOM, cropped and resized to 224x224 pixels
performance_results: trCNN showed very high accuracy, more than 90% of the images were correctly labelled
data_type: Pre- and post-contrast T1 images and T2 images
ai_goal: To distinguish between meningiomas and gliomas in dogs using MRI to aid in correct therapy choice

title: Evaluation of the VETSCAN IMAGYST: an in-clinic canine and feline fecal parasite detection system integrated with a deep learning algorithm
data_heterogeneity: The study used fecal samples from dogs and cats, with variations in sample consistency and parasite egg counts.
preprocessing: Fecal slides were prepared using VETSCAN IMAGYST centrifugal and passive flotation techniques; samples were preserved at 4°C or fixed with 10% formalin solution.
performance_results: Sensitivity and specificity were calculated, with Pearson's correlation coefficients ranging from 0.83 to 0.99 for different parasites and methods.
ml_algorithm: Deep learning object detection algorithm using SSD with Inception v2 backbone
ai_goal: To detect and identify parasite eggs in fecal samples from dogs and cats using automated deep learning techniques.

title: Bridging clinic and wildlife care with AI-powered pan-species computational pathology
data_heterogeneity: Data from 20 different species, including mammals, reptiles, aves, and amphibians
preprocessing: Slide digitalisation, quality control protocols, single-cell annotations
performance_results: Accuracy for canine transmissible venereal tumour: 0.94; Tasmanian devil facial tumour disease: 0.88; other species accuracy ranged 0.57–0.94
species_breed: 20 vertebrate species including mammalia, reptilia, aves, and amphibia
ai_goal: To study cancer morphology and immune response across species, and to provide prognostic value in veterinary medicine

title: cnn-based diagnosis models for canine ulcerative keratitis
data_heterogeneity: Images from different veterinary hospitals, various stages of corneal ulcers
preprocessing: Images resized to 224x224 pixels, cropped to exclude non-coronal areas
performance_results: Accuracies over 90% for classifying all types of corneal ulcers
ai_goal: To determine corneal ulcer severity in dogs

title: Automatic classification of canine thoracic radiographs using deep learning
small_dataset_techniques: Data augmentation (random horizontal/vertical flips, cropping, affine warping, linear contrast changes)
data_heterogeneity: Data from two different radiograph acquisition systems, handling of various radiographic findings
preprocessing: Normalization to 0-1 range, exclusion of improperly exposed or positioned images, assessment of image quality
evaluation_metrics: AUC, sensitivity, specificity, positive likelihood ratio (PLR), negative likelihood ratio (NLR)
performance_results: Variable accuracy across different radiographic findings, with AUC values provided for each finding
ml_algorithm: Deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with ResNet-50 and DenseNet-121 architectures
ai_goal: Classification of thoracic radiographs in dogs to assist veterinarians

title: Deep learning for necrosis detection using canine perivascular wall tumour whole slide images
data_heterogeneity: Canine Soft Tissue Sarcoma (cSTS) are a heterogeneous group of mesenchymal neoplasms
preprocessing: RGB mean and standard deviation values per fold for patch image normalization
performance_results: F1-score of 0.708, accuracy, precision, sensitivity, and specificity values detailed in confusion matrices
ml_algorithm: DenseNet-161 Convolutional Neural Network, ensemble models, logistic regression
ai_goal: Automatic necrosis detection in canine Perivascular Wall Tumour (cPWT) Whole Slide Images (WSIs) for improving the precision of tumour grading

title: An AI-based algorithm for the automatic evaluation of image quality in canine thoracic radiographs
small_dataset_techniques: Data augmentation (affine transformation, random cropping, flips, contrast changes)
data_heterogeneity: Data from three veterinary clinics in Italy, using both computed radiology (CR) and direct radiology (DR) systems
preprocessing: DICOM files converted to MetaImage Medical Format (MHA), resampled to 224x224 pixels, normalized by Z-normalization specific to ResNet-50
evaluation_metrics: AUC, sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative likelihood ratios (PLR and NLR)
performance_results: Overall accuracy of 81.5% in latero-lateral and 75.7% in sagittal images; AUC of 0.93 for limb mispositioning in latero-lateral images, AUC of 0.92 in sagittal images
ai_goal: To develop and test an AI-based algorithm for detecting common technical errors in canine thoracic radiography

title: Improving the classification of veterinary thoracic radiographs through inter-species and inter-pathology self-supervised pre-training of deep learning models
small_dataset_techniques: Self-supervised learning, fine-tuning with a smaller dataset, balancing sampler for class representation
data_heterogeneity: Used data from multiple species and pathologies, managed with self-supervised learning techniques
preprocessing: Image resizing to 224x224 pixels, normalization to intensity range 0-1
evaluation_metrics: ROC AUC, sensitivity, specificity, positive likelihood ratio (PLR), negative likelihood ratio (NLR)
performance_results: AUC scores of 0.77 and 0.66 for laterolateral and dorsoventral projection datasets respectively
ml_algorithm: Self-supervised learning models including Beta Variational Autoencoder, Soft-Introspective Variational Autoencoder, Simple Framework for Contrastive Learning of Visual Representations
ai_goal: Automatic multi-label classification of lesions in veterinary radiographs

title: AI-based prediction and detection of early-onset of digital dermatitis in dairy cows using infrared thermography
performance_results: Accuracy above 81% for DD detection on day 0, above 70% for prediction two days prior, 88% for detecting active DD lesions
ml_algorithm: Deep learning, Nu-Support Vector Classification (NuSVC), Gaussian Naive Bayes
data_type: Thermal images, statistical color features, manually registered temperature values
ai_goal: Prediction and early detection of digital dermatitis in dairy cows

title: Diagnostic Classification of Cases of Canine Leishmaniasis Using Machine Learning
data_heterogeneity: Data from 340 dogs with 18 variables collected from a specific region, indicating some level of heterogeneity in the dataset.
preprocessing: Recursive feature elimination with cross-validation was used to select the best variables for the models.
evaluation_metrics: Accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, positive likelihood ratio, negative likelihood ratio, AUROC
performance_results: Logistic regression achieved the best metrics: Accuracy of 75%, sensitivity of 84%, specificity of 67%, positive likelihood ratio of 2.53, negative likelihood ratio of 0.23, AUROC of 0.77.
ml_algorithm: Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine, K-Nearest Neighbor, Naïve Bayes
ai_goal: To classify cases of canine visceral leishmaniasis based on physical examinations without laboratory tests.

title: Artificial intelligence evaluating primary thoracic lesions has an overall lower error rate compared to veterinarians or veterinarians in conjunction with the artificial intelligence
small_dataset_techniques: Pretraining with ImageNet and CheXpert, data augmentation
data_heterogeneity: Dataset included canine and feline patients, no preselection regarding medical conditions, age, gender, or breed, which introduced natural heterogeneity
preprocessing: DICOM images converted to smaller matrix, random flipping, rotating, and zooming of images
evaluation_metrics: Error rates, McNemar’s test, area under the receiver operator characteristic curve (AUC)
performance_results: Statistically significant improvement in error rates for 'alveolar pattern' and 'cardiomegaly' when veterinarians were aided by the AI
ai_goal: To develop an AI system for screening thoracic radiographs for primary thoracic lesions in feline and canine patients

title: Classification of neoplastic and inflammatory brain disease using MRI texture analysis in 119 dogs
data_heterogeneity: Data heterogeneity was managed by using a variety of MR image acquisition parameters, which varied by patient size and the receiver coil used.
preprocessing: Texture metrics were extracted using the LIFEx freeware program; additional texture features and filters were described but not evaluated in this study.
species_breed: Dogs, including specific breeds like Boxers, Boston Terriers, French Bulldogs, Pit Bull Terriers, Pugs, Chihuahuas, Maltese, and Yorkshire Terriers
ai_goal: To apply texture analysis to MR examinations of the brain in dogs to predict the underlying etiology of brain diseases

title: Machine learning predicts histologic type and grade of canine gliomas based on MRI texture analysis
data_heterogeneity: Data from different segments and sequences of MRI, handling of imbalanced dataset with higher proportion of certain glioma types
preprocessing: Manual segmentation, normalization of MRI gray levels, z-score normalization, principal component analysis for dimensionality reduction
performance_results: Accuracy up to 94%, sensitivity and specificity not explicitly detailed for all models
ml_algorithm: Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), k-nearest neighbors (kNN)
ai_goal: To predict histologic types and grades of canine gliomas using MRI texture analysis

title: An artificial neural network-based model to predict chronic kidney disease in aged cats
data_heterogeneity: Data from different sources and time periods, including a diverse group of cats over 20 years
preprocessing: Factorial discriminant analysis used for variable selection; data cleaning involved excluding variables with high missing data and those not relevant or consistent
evaluation_metrics: Accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), area under the curve (AUC)
performance_results: Accuracy up to 90%, sensitivity 83-97%, specificity 23-93%, PPV 27-70%, NPV close to 1
ml_algorithm: Artificial neural network (ANN) with multilayer feed-forward neural network and back-propagation algorithm
data_type: Clinical data including plasma creatinine, blood urea concentrations, urine specific gravity
ai_goal: To build a sensitive and specific model for early prediction of chronic kidney disease (CKD) in cats
